column4: Spectator -- Create a file with a name like S999_iwconfig, and inside it put the commands you manually run to get the wireless card to work
Make sure it has 700 permissions "sudo chmod 700 filename" and put it in the /etc/rcx.d/ directories
The numbers mean the different runlevels -- man runlevel for info on those
Every script in rcx.d runs whenever the computer starts in runlevel x
Spectator -- Yes, instead of x they are numbers.  Like /etc/rc5.d, or /etc/rc2.d
Spectator -- I think by default you only need to put it in /etc/rc2.d
it isn't what I prefer, it's what du allows
-- They're two different things -s shows a summary, --max-depth stops it from display subdirectories.
Try them, they both do different things than just du -h
quoted from the man page:  "--max-depth=0" is the same as --summaraize.  However I didn't know you could use max-depth with du.
however, the result is identical:  du -sh *
